The Anglo-Saxon Chronicle records King William
I, (the Conqueror), Duke of Normandy, wearing

63.text:
his crown at Salisbury in August 1086, surrounded
by all of his earls, barons, and other principal

70.text:
landholders in his Norman kingdom of England,
that was only twenty years old and won by

76.text:
conquest at the Battle of Hastings in 1066.
These great men had gathered because a survey

83.text:
of the kingdom was complete, and their holdings
duly recorded beyond peradventure of doubt.

90.text:
They had come to swear fealty and to make
homage to the King for their lands, as recorded

96.text:
in the royal land inquiry.
They were cementing a relationship of great

101.text:
religious moment between monarch and chief
vassals, a relationship that could hardly

106.text:
have been more permanent than if it had been
hewn in stone, like the Ten Commandments,

111.text:
though it was written on sheep skins, which
have endured very much better than Moses'

117.text:
tablets.
The court at Salisbury was so important an

122.text:
occasion in the feudal nexus of allegiance
and loyalty, oaths given to the King in return

128.text:
for land and privileges - which the King's
law would uphold for the tenant who was true

133.text:
to his word - that this record of landowners
and their property soon became known as Domesday

139.text:
Book, literally, the final arbiter on ownership,
duties, responsbilities, privileges that arose

147.text:
from the possession of land.
From King William's point of view, it was

152.text:
the ultimate record of who owed what to the
crown, as supreme landlord of England, in

159.text:
return for their shares in the conquest. It
was the last word on property rights, and

165.text:
the evidence contained in it was soon thought
of as the 'Last Trump of Doom,' By the end

171.text:
of the twelfth century, it was called Domesday
Book.

174.text:
No one knows why for certain - perhaps because
it was like the Last Judgment when the trumpets

180.text:
are to be sounded and Christ will come to
judge the quick and the dead. The word 'doom'

185.text:
- D. double O. M. - is an ancient Anglo-Saxon
word, meaning a a 'judgment', having the effect

192.text:
of a law, and we shall meet Anglo-Saxon kings'
dooms later. Maybe Domesday derives from this

200.text:
But we have almost seven centuries to recount
before we reach Salisbury in 1086, for the

207.text:
plot of this drama is long and winding, with
every kind of vice and virtue displayed as

213.text:
we go.
We shall not be able to begin to understand

why there was a Norman conquest and why the

until we understand the centuries that preceded

236.text:
The pre-history of Britain, beginning about
ten thousand years ago, after the last Ice

241.text:
Age, when people from continental Europe colonized
this island, is barely known. There have been

248.text:
archaeological discoveries, and consequent
speculation, but these are not history.

254.text:
History means recorded history, history written
down, and we do not really have any of that

260.text:
until the middle of the first century BC in
The Conquest of Gaul, written by Julius Caesar,

268.text:
who made two unsuccessful invasions of southern
Britain, in 55 and 54BC.

274.text:
In my school days, we all soon learned Caesar's
famous fib, veni, vidi, vici (the first Latin

281.text:
for most of us) - 'I came, I saw, I conquered.'
Well, he came and he saw, but the conquest

287.text:
had to wait until AD43 and the Emperor Claudius,
who conquered and annexed Britain - Britannia,

294.text:
as the Romans called it - the last province
to be added long-term to the Roman Empire.

299.text:
Roman legions were withdrawn from Britain
in AD381 because Rome itself was under threat,

308.text:
and the Island at the Edge of the World was
cut adrift.

312.text:
I have entitled my discussion as I have because
Britain was at the edge of the known world.

318.text:
Look at the map I have made of the Euro-Asian
land mass. On the left, we have the enormous

324.text:
Roman Empire, on the right the enormous Chinese
Empire.

329.text:
In between we have the Persian Empire, the
Indian kingdoms and empires, the south Asian

335.text:
kingdoms of the Silk Road between East and
West. These states and many I have not named

341.text:
were the civilized world as known in about
AD400, though the map of the sort I am showing

347.text:
would have had no meaning to people then.
They had writing, without which organized

352.text:
government is impossible; they had trade,
currency, art, literature, philosophy, luxury,

360.text:
religion, numerical, linear-, weight-, and
volume-calculation, astronomy, astrology,

368.text:
medicine - well, everything really, but not
maps of the sort I am showing.

373.text:
What they had was representations of the world,
like the one I am now showing, made in the

378.text:
second century by Claudius Ptolemy, a Greek
from Alexandria, in Egypt.

384.text:
It was not intended as a navigation map, but
- with Rome at its centre - Ptolemy's map

389.text:
was meant to demonstrate the overwhelming
authority of Roman emperors and the civilized

394.text:
fineness of all things that emanated out of
their great imperial city.

400.text:
Maps that we know in atlases and, until SatNav,
in road gazeteers did not begin for another

406.text:
one thousand seven hundred years, in the eighteenth
century.

411.text:
To the east of the land mass was nothing but
the Pacific Ocean, and to the West the Atlantic.

418.text:
Except for a short visit by Vikings in the
eleventh century, the American continent would

422.text:
not be discovered by the peoples of the Euro-Asian
land mass until the fifteenth century, first,

428.text:
by the Chinese, who did not stay, and a bit
later in that century by the Europeans, in

433.text:
the person of Christopher Columbus.
The coastal strip of North Africa and some

439.text:
way down the River Nile were known, but Africa
was otherwise a void until Vasco Da Gama,

445.text:
also in the fifteenth century, set out from
Portugal, and sailed round the Cape of Good

450.text:
Hope, and up the east coast of Africa to India.
Australia, New Zealand, and the Pacific islands

457.text:
were not discovered by Europeans, until the
seventeenth to the nineteenth centuries: the

463.text:
civilized world's contribution to the last
group having once been described as bringing

468.text:
'gunpowder, print, and the Protestant religion'
- we ought not to forget syphilis.

474.text:
Britain, therefore, as a place known to history,
was at the very edge of the world in AD381

482.text:
and would remain so for many centuries to
come.

485.text:
In our story, we shall encounter Britons who
were synonymous with Welsh and Cornish people;

492.text:
Angles, Saxons, and Jutes; Gauls, Franks,
Frisians, Picts, and Irish who were really

499.text:
Scots; Norsemen, whom I shall mostly call
'Vikings' until the end of the 10th century,

504.text:
when I shall call them Danes; and then Normans.
There will be lesser groups. Some of these

511.text:
races were conquerors and the Normans were
the most successful conquerors of them all.

517.text:
What lies before us is like an enormous Hollywood
epic that Cecil B De Mille might have liked

523.text:
to produce, but whose actors will include
real people, playing themselves: Roman emperors,

529.text:
popes, princes, princesses, kings, queens,
pirates, rapists, thieves, martyrs, holy men

537.text:
- bad and good - saints, story-tellers, whom
we call chroniclers.

544.text:
Names that still resonate include SS Gregory
and Augustine, the Venerable Bede, now canonized,

551.text:
Alfred the Great, King Cnut, Edward the Confessor,
and, of course, William the Conqueror.

557.text:
We shall come across incomparable wealth in
the treasure houses of kings and noblemen,

562.text:
to contrast with the meagre livelihoods of
unnamed thousands of men and women, whose

568.text:
only fault in these tumultuous centuries was
to be at the bottom of the social and political

577.text:
We shall find armies and navies, battles and
hostage-taking, massacres and burnings of

583.text:
whole towns; gruesome executions, blindings,
and maimings; shocking natural disasters,

590.text:
attributed to acts of God visited on a wicked
people.

594.text:
Infidelity in men, it has been well said,
is as common as rain, and we shall encounter

599.text:
killers of their fathers, their mothers, their
brothers, and their sisters - rulers who can

604.text:
use anyone, even a man of honour.
We shall also find fabulous artworks, wise

611.text:
law codes, just rulers, great kindnesses,
acts of selfless charity, and love affairs

620.text:
It is a story mainly about how the Christian
world spread and took root in the British

626.text:
Isles, but also elsewhere, to become the plinth
on which the pillar of Western civilization

631.text:
stands, and to which it remains cemented,
despite the rapid secularization of our society

637.text:
since the end of the Second World War in 1945.
We used to believe in religious myths, now

644.text:
we believe in secular ones. Kings and emperors
have been replaced by presidents and prime

649.text:
ministers whose acolytes and apologists include
scientists, sociologists, lords of industry

655.text:
and commerce, journalists, television news
presenters, even actors and pop singers, and

661.text:
people like me, you might think, as this story
rolls along.

666.text:
You may well wonder, as we move through the
centuries, whether we are making a history

669.text:
of Christianity, or a history of the people
who now comprise what I call - not uniquely

675.text:
We shall be doing both because, without Christianity,
we shall never arrive at a proper understanding

682.text:
of the countries that comprise our islands
At the Edge of the World, and Christianity

687.text:
- or how Christianity was interpreted - is
the continuous thread that links everything

691.text:
together. Perhaps it still does, if in less
intense ways than in the Anglo-Saxon period.

698.text:
I shall be digressing, throughout this documentary,
from the Anglo-Saxon Christian past to the

703.text:
British present, in which symbols and proselytes,
rituals and beliefs - having different names

709.text:
and titles today, being even atheistic - are
essentially derived from a Christian heritage

714.text:
of martyrology and have their own form of
righteousness, little different - except in

719.text:
nomenclature - from old Canon - or Church
- Law, their own inquisitions, preachers,

saints, and sinners.
The burning debate - literally, by some lights

- of Global Warming among scientists and politicians

death by the scarlet flame those who question

Before we go into detail to set the all-important
religious context of our period, we must go

759.text:
back again to Salisbury in 1086, where we

followers. What was England like then?
(I say England not to ignore the Scots or

the Welsh, but because we actually have a
reasonably clear picture of the kingdom from

the English chronicles and, of course, that

Jane Cox, a principal assistant keeper at
what was the Public Record Office, organized

an exhibition to mark the Great Survey's ninth

The Public Record Office, or PRO, is now called

London, and is where the original Exchequer

807.text:
Mrs Cox reminds us in the guide to her Exhibition
that England was probably the richest monarchy

813.text:
in Europe. We shall see why much later in
this documentary. The land was cultuivated

818.text:
to a large extent in vast fields where hedgerows,
which still define much of rural England today,

824.text: hardly existed at all. She tells us:

829.text:
The primeval forests had long been cleared
and the land was wooded about as much as modern

834.text:
France. Settlements were old established and,
except for the far north, there was no spot

840.text:
from which half a day's walk would not bring
you to a house. Many Roman roads had been

845.text:
maintained, communications were good, and

849.text:
The idea, therefore, that Robin Hood and his
merry men, a century or so later, could hide

854.text:
out in Sherwood Forest, Nottinghamshire, is
fiction. Indeed, as a lover of the hunt - like

859.text:
all great men of the time - William the Conqueror
planted forests, one in south-west Hampshire,

864.text:
so that he could pursue this sport.
That forest is still called the New Forest

870.text:
because it was new and it was needed in the
eleventh century, the king and many of his

875.text:
suceessors decreed. There were still wolves
and wild boar, but you may not know that there

880.text:
wern't any rabbits. These were introduced
by the Normans for hunting with the bow.

885.text:
I need hardly say that there were none of
the modern conveniences, but some absences,

890.text:
that we take for granted today, may surprise.
There was no sugar. There were no potatoes,

898.text:
tomatoes, spinach, oranges, lemons, coffee,
tea.

902.text:
There were no horse chestnut trees, so there
were no conkers for boys to play with against

907.text:
each other. I remember having a sevener, a
conker with which I won seven contests before

914.text:
it was shattered by another boy in a playground
competition, where you took it in turns to

918.text:
hit the opponent's conker with your own, both
suspended on a knotted string.

924.text:
Where conkers are still permitted in schools,
I believe that contestants must now wear safety

932.text:
Wine from these shores is not new, though
you might think so. Twenty-four vineyards

938.text:
are recorded in Domesday Book, and British
wine, as it was called, is mentioned with

942.text:
praise by Tacitus, a Roman historian living
in the early second century AD, which suggests

949.text:
that the climate was warm enough for vines
